docs.lead_paragraph: HAVING downsized in the 90's, many executives are probably beginning to wonder how they should prepare for the 21st century. As the nation returns to work after Labor Day, the producers of a public-broadcasting documentary based on the 1984 book ''In Search of Excellence'' have suggestions. They chose eight companies for ''The Excellence Files,'' which will be presented nationally by New York-based Thirteen/WNET on Tuesday at 9 P.M. Sam Tyler, one of the executive producers, said that the eight companies -- which range from the global consumer-product giant Coca-Cola to a Boston consulting firm, Work/Family Directions -- represent ''the next wave of management thinking.''

headline.main: How to Succeed in the Labor Relations Business by Trying

docs.abstract: Public-broadcasting documentary, The Excellence Files, profiles eight companies that represent next wave of management thinking; Sam Tyler, executive producer, says this involves understanding personal and family issues that employees bring with them when they come to work every day (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S not as though Panda Kroll and Kevin Volkan are undereducated. Between them, they have six college degrees. Mr. Volkan even has two doctorates in psychology. But earlier this month, the couple, who have been married for 10 years, moved from California to Boston to work on two more degrees -- and giving up work that brings in $130,000 a year. Mr. Volkan, 38, plans to study public health at Harvard University, where he hopes to earn a master's degree in one academic year. Ms. Kroll, 36, is entering law school at Boston University and will not get a degree until 2000. As a result, the couple's financial picture during the next three years will take on an entirely new math, requiring

headline.main: Six Diplomas Later, They're Going Back to School

docs.abstract: Article in occasional series Fresh Start, about personal finance decisions; Panda Kroll and Kevin Volkan, both in their 30's, discuss decision to give up beach cottage and incomes in California to attend graduate schools in Boston; interview; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The flow of drinking water to New York City begins as far away as a damp spot under some leaves on a mountainside 120 miles north of Times Square. For 155 years, the city has maintained a complicated network of reservoirs and aqueducts to carry rain and melted snow from distant hills to bathtubs in Brooklyn and sinks on Staten Island. Now the purity of that flow faces the gravest threats ever, from both old sewage systems and a new wave of unbridled development in the watershed. To combat those threats, a growing force of scientists, engineers, special police officers and others from the city's Department of Environmental Protection has fanned out this summer across suburbs and farmland to explain and enforce the first new pollution rules for the watershed in 44 years.

headline.main: Billion-Dollar Plan to Clean New York City Water at Its Source

docs.lead_paragraph: GONE are the days when even a healthy pregnancy was looked upon as a delicate condition requiring constant bed rest or some measure of confinement. Travel -- for work or pleasure -- has become a way of life for many women, and it is not often easy or desirable to leave it behind for a full nine months. Many travel clinics report a steady stream of pregnant clients with questions ranging from the safety of weapons-detection devices at airports (specialists agree they are safe) to the treatment of illnesses they might face on the road. Barring complications like hypertension, a history of miscarriages, diabetes or bleeding -- conditions that must be monitored closely -- most obstetricians are willing to give a thumbs-up to a sensible travel plan, especially in the second trimester.

headline.main: When One Must Travel For Two

docs.abstract: Practical Traveler column discusses issues pregnant traveler should consider in order to ensure comfortable and safe trip for both herself and her fetus, including when to travel, air and car travel, and high-risk countries; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I enjoyed Loch Adamson's article ''When Creativity Runs in the Family'' $(Aug. 17$), but what happens when the family is not of the ''rich and famous'' variety? As both a struggling painter and a parent of a dedicated musician, I am scared to death about my child's survival.
docs.abstract: Francine Funk letter discusses Loch Adamson's Aug 17 article on creativity in families (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH the teamsters' success in their two-week strike against United Parcel Service, and with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. training thousands of union organizers in a drive to reverse a quarter-century of declining membership, millions of workers will be asked over the next few years whether they want a union to represent them. It is a complicated question, the answer to which rests on a jumble of determinations: Do you favor collective action or individual initiative? Do you trust the union's leaders? Do you want somebody else speaking for you in dealings with your employer? Do you think you will be dismissed if you sign a union card -- or that the company will send your job overseas if a union is organized?

headline.main: On Payday, Union Jobs Stack Up Very Well

docs.abstract: Economists with varying perspectives agree that, from pocketbook perspective, workers are absolutely better off joining a union, and turning nonunion job into union job will likely have greater effect on lifetime finances than any other advice workers can take; Prof Richard B Freeman notes that, if there are losers in organizing drive, they are people who might have gotten job in future, shareholders whose profits will go down, managers who will have less to share among themselves and, perhaps, consumers; union workers overall are paid about 20 percent more than nonunion workers, and fringe benefits are typically worth two to four times as much; photos of recently-unionized asbestos-removal workers; graphs showing financial benefits and, paradoxically, decline in union membership in US since 1984 (M)
